awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Integrated Design of Intelligent Structures with Tailored Distributed Damping
awd_abstract_narration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program research project aims to investigate a fundamentally new approach for designing intelligent structures for vibration and motion control, create new numerical design strategies, and to generate a foundational understanding for how best to design this new class of intelligent structures. Existing intelligent structures use integrated sensors and actuators, such as piezoelectric materials, distributed across the surface or interior of a flexible elastic material to control dynamic behavior. Here embedded viscoelastic materials (VEMs) are introduced to overcome current performance limitations. Incorporating VEMs is challenging because 1) engineers cannot rely on past experience to design this unprecedented system, and 2) accurate VEM models are computationally expensive. Here new integrated design optimization strategies will be used to accelerate generation of design knowledge for this new type of intelligent structure, and to reduce computational expense. Numerical and physical experiments will center on application to precision pointing for space-based telescopes. More precise pointing has the potential to enhance significantly scientific data gathering, including search for exoplanets. These advances also have potential to advance other domains where ultra-quiet structural stability or precision motion control is critical (e.g., manufacturing, robotics, and defense). Education and outreach components of this CAREER project involve the creation of unique hands-on activities that allow K-12 and undergraduate students to experience the value of design automation tools. These are enhanced by collaborations with the "Girls do Science" program at the Orpheum Children's Museum and a CubeSat project with NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory.

Intelligent structures (IS) have been studied extensively, but primarily for active damping as opposed to motion control, and have largely avoided incorporation of spatially distributed VEMs for damping. Inclusion of VEMs and extension to motion control could help achieve new performance levels, but introduces a profound design challenge as no design history, validated design guidelines, or expert intuition exist. Current IS technology utilizes spatially distributed control actuation to tailor dynamic behavior. Recent work has combined control tailoring with distributed geometric elastic substructure design. A remaining obstacle is control of high-order structural modes in practical implementations, and is addressed here via strategically distributed VEMs to damp high-order modes passively. VEM distribution can be varied spatially to synergize with elastic material and control distribution. This enhances design flexibility, but this adds a new level of complexity. A new concept for integrated dynamic system design optimization where surrogate models of the state space derivative function are constructed and improved adaptively is planned. This capitalizes on the intrinsic properties of dynamic systems for numerical efficiency. VEMs can be modeled accurately, but with great computational expense, using high-order ordinary differential equation (ODE) approximations. The new derivative function surrogate modeling (DFSM) strategy is posited to produce high-accuracy VEM modeling using efficient low-order ODEs with state-dependent parameters. DFSM adjusts parameter mappings adaptively to improve accuracy, which supports efficient low-order computation. After thorough study of DFSM for damped IS design, DFSM will then be used for rapid design exploration and systematic generation of design data. Machine learning strategies will then be used to identify patterns and relationships within this data. An iterative inductive process will be used to identify possible design guidelines from these results, such as preferred distributed shape relationships or sensor/actuator/VEM placement guidelines. Additional numerical design studies will be used to validate/refine design guidelines.

por.por_cntn:
At early stages of engineering design, the effect of design decisions is difficult to predict. This can result in costly surprises when testing hardware prototypes at later stages. One factor here is the difficulty in utilizing accurate computational models during early-stage design. In this project, novel approaches to integrated (early-stage) design optimization methods for actively controlled systems were investigated. The integrated methods belong to a class of methods known as Control Co-Design (CCD). A breakthrough in fundamental CCD problem formulation was made that 1) simultaneously reduces the computational expense and enhances early-stage design decision accuracy for certain classes of actively-controlled engineering systems, and 2) expanded the range of problems that could be solved using these novel methods, including application to spacecraft attitude control and renewable wind and water energy. These CCD advancements were leveraged to investigate design knowledge extraction using machine learning from CCD optimization data (supported by an NSF Data Science Supplement for this project). Furthermore, the intellectual and societal impact of this project has been amplified profoundly through follow-on support. The breakthroughs in CCD enabled by this project led to over $150MM in U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) investment in using CCD as a strategy to produce disruptive improvements in the cost of renewable energy through the ARPA-E ATLANTIS and SHARKS programs. These programs also supported the creation of an open-source tool (WEIS) led by the National Renewable Energy Laboratory that is now being used for CCD optimization of renewable energy systems by practicing engineers. The research supported by this project has therefore had large-scale direct impact on engineering practice. The CCD research in this project also led to an NSF workshop on CCD hosted at UIUC (NSF Award #1935895). A new course in CCD focused on practical engineering application has been created that is accessible to undergraduate students and practicing engineers, and will serve as the core of a new certificate program in CCD. Numerous undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral researchers have received training in scientific study of engineering design methods through participation in this project. 

 

The core technical advancements of this project were: 1) breakthrough CCD capabilities through creation and analysis of advanced Derivative Function Surrogate Modeling (DFSM) methods, and 2) discovery of a completely new spacecraft attitude control system with the potential to replace flywheel-based technologies and significantly improve the reliability and capability of spacecraft reorientation systems (impacting areas such as space telescopes for exoplanet search or systems for deep-space optical communication). The concept of DFSM was discovered not long before this project was proposed, but only initial investigations had been performed. DFSM capitalizes upon the structure of certain classes of CCD optimization problems, including those where derivative functions for dynamic system models are not available directly, to solve CCD optimization problems that previously were impossible or impractical. The initial DFSM studies were limited to low-dimension problems. The advancements from this project has led to an order-of-magnitude increase in solvable problem dimension and enhanced model fidelity. This was a critical performance threshold that made DFSM practical for problems of great societal importance. Through associated projects funded by the DOE, CCD tools that incorporate DFSM have been matured and released as open-source software that has been adopted by industry for the design of renewable energy systems. 

 

The second technical advancement involves the core CCD application case study for this project: Strain-Actuated Solar Arrays (SASA) for spacecraft attitude control. SASA used intelligent structural appendages equipped with distributed piezoelectric actuators to provide fine-pointing and jitter reduction capabilities for spacecraft without the need for expensive isolation systems. SASA provided a rich design problem that was very effective for the study of CCD optimization methods. SASA, however, could only produce small angle slew reorientations, and a supplementary large-angle attitude control system was needed, such as reaction wheel assemblies (RWAs). RWAs introduce vibration into spacecraft, and exhibit reliability problems (e.g., the failed NASA Kepler planet-hunting space telescope). A discovery made during the analysis of SASA simulations revealed that an elegant extension to the SASA control strategy could produce arbitrarily-large slew maneuvers, eliminating the need for RWAs. This is achieved using non-holonomic control trajectories that vary appendage mass moment of inertia during the maneuver cycle. This new technology is now known as Multifunctional Structures for Attitude Control (MSAC). The MSAC breakthrough could revolutionize spacecraft attitude control, as well as other precision motion control applications. This project involved initial MSAC hardware tests that demonstrated its viability and revealed fundamental characteristics. These results garnered broader interest that has led to multiple patent applications and follow-on projects that have increased MSAC Technology Readiness Level from 1 to 6. A new company, Samara Aerospace, has been formed to further develop and commercialize MSAC technology and move it toward adoption in a range of spacecraft missions.
